author: By Sam Roberts
title: E. Gerald Corrigan, Who Helped Ease ’87 Stock Crash, Dies at 80
description: As president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, he favored flooding the financial system with cash to restore confidence among investors.
content: E. Gerald Corrigan, who as the aggressive president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank helped cushion Wall Street’s crash in the late 1980s, died on May 17 in a memory-care center in Dedham, Mass. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Nelson
title: The Pitfalls of Oven-Ready TV
description: Prestige shows like “Winning Time” love to dramatize the real people at the heart of recent-ish events. It doesn’t always go well.
content: It’s May 1980 at the Forum in Los Angeles, and the crowd is in a frenzy as the rookie Magic Johnson and the legend Kareem Abdul-Jabbar lead the Lakers to their first N.B.A. championship in eight years. This is the setting for the recently completed first season of HBO’s “Winning Time: The Rise of the Lakers Dynasty,” which dives into its subject matter with brio. Helmed by the ubiquitous Adam McKay — director of “The Big Short,” “Don’t Look Up” and a parade of successful film comedies — “Winning Time” is an antic chronicle of the Lakers’ highly eventful 1979-80 season, with main characters that include not just Johnson and Abdul-Jabbar but other Lakers titans like the coach Pat Riley and the owner Jerry Buss. Its 10-episode arc is fast and fun, full of on-court magnetism and off-court machismo, and it all actually happened. Sort of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Four Takeaways From Tuesday’s Elections
description: Georgia voters rejected Donald Trump’s 2020 fixation, G.O.P. governors proved their strength, and Georgia Democrats backed a gun-control champion on the day of a horrifying school shooting in Texas.
content: Tuesday was a booming repudiation of former President Donald J. Trump’s relentless preoccupation with the 2020 election. In Georgia, his voter-fraud-focused choices for governor and attorney general were roundly defeated, while his pick for secretary of state lost to a man who stood up to those false claims two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Katie Benner
title: The Uvalde massacre raises the stakes for hearings on Biden’s pick to run the A.T.F.
description: The killings came less than 24 hours before a former prosecutor, Steven Dettelbach, was scheduled to face a grilling from Senate Republicans.
content: WASHINGTON — White House officials knew the confirmation hearings for President Biden’s nominee to lead the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives would be a make-or-break moment for his stalled agenda on gun control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: When Jim Crow Violence Came to a Small New York Village
description: Philip Dray’s book “A Lynching at Port Jervis” unearths the history of an 1892 murder of a Black man at the hands of a white mob.
content: On June 2, 1892, a white mob seized a Black man and hanged him from the high branch of an old maple tree in Port Jervis, N.Y. Several days later, a jury took all of an hour to deliver its verdict on what had happened: “Robert Lewis came to his death in the village of Port Jervis on June 2nd by being hanged by his neck by a person or persons unknown.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Peck and J. David Goodman
title: 19 Children and 2 Adults Killed in Massacre at Texas Elementary School
description: The mass shooting was the deadliest at an American school since the slayings at Sandy Hook a decade ago.
content: Follow the latest news on Uvalde, Texas, elementary school shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charley Locke
title: ‘Grandfluencers’ Are Sharing a New Vision of Old Age
description: On TikTok, the over-65 set is thriving.
content: CATHEDRAL CITY, Calif. — Robert Reeves, 78, spends most days lounging by the pool, taking in the low-desert sun with his friends and neighbors. The four of them talk about what’s new — recovery from a recent corrective foot surgery, some chronic inflammation issues — and record videos for social media, where they’ve amassed millions of followers as the Old Gays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: On Somber Night, Mavericks’ Crucial Win Draws Muted Celebration
description: Dallas staved off elimination by Golden State behind Luka Doncic’s near triple-double. But the mass shooting in Uvalde loomed over the game.
content: DALLAS — After a second-quarter stoppage in play, Luka Doncic of the Mavericks rose from one leg and tossed up a meaningless shot from beyond the 3-point line whose sole purpose seemed to be to entertain Doncic himself. It was a skyscraper, the ball hurtling toward the rafters before plummeting to Earth. It took one hard bounce off the court and then rattled through the hoop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson
title: Democrats moved quickly to clear the way for votes on legislation to strengthen background checks for gun purchasers.
description: Republicans have opposed such measures in the past, and gave no indication that they had changed their positions.
content: Within hours of the shooting in Uvalde, Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, moved to clear the way to force votes in coming days on legislation that would strengthen background checks for gun purchasers, pushing to revive measures with broad appeal that Republicans have blocked in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Vowed Vengeance, but Georgia Voters Rejected His Meddling
description: The president’s endorsed candidates were losers up and down the primary ballot, raising questions about the firmness of his grip on the Republican Party.
content: Donald J. Trump barreled into Georgia vowing to marshal voters against his enemies and punish Republicans who crossed him in 2020. Instead, Georgia voters punished him for meddling in their state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Corporations Pledge to Buy ‘Green’ at Davos Gathering
description: A global buyers’ club of more than 50 companies, including Microsoft and Ford Motor, say they will buy “green” steel, aluminum and other commodities by 2030.
content: WASHINGTON — More than 50 corporations have joined a global “buyers’ club” that pledges to purchase aluminum, steel and other commodities made from processes that emit little to no carbon, a move that will be announced on Wednesday by leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Democrats Confront 2 Obstacles on Guns: Time, and an Implacable G.O.P.
description: After the slaughter of Texas schoolchildren, the parties are already reprising their familiar roles: Democrats are pushing for action on gun control, while Republicans wait for the furor to fade away.
content: Three days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Mother Courage’ Review: Selling Her Wares Amid the Havoc of War
description: Irondale Ensemble’s adaptation of Brecht’s antiwar epic captures some of its spirit but lacks any real philosophical or political heft.
content: There’s no virtue in war. But there is profit — for those ruthless enough to get it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: Bolt, the payments start-up, has begun laying off employees.
description: The Silicon Valley company cut jobs on Wednesday amid a souring fund-raising environment for start-ups.
content: Bolt, the fast-growing online payments start-up that was valued at $11 billion earlier this year but recently instituted a hiring freeze as the wider market wobbled, began laying people off on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: Peaches Reflects on Her Seminal Album, ‘The Teaches of Peaches’
description: The electroclash pioneer looks back on her influential album 20 years later.
content: In advance of a tour celebrating the 20th anniversary of her 2000 album “The Teaches of Peaches,” the performance artist and musician Merrill Nisker, 55, who is better known as Peaches, dug into her archive. The archive is not metaphorical, but a storage unit full of photos, video footage and costumes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Jimmy Carter, at 97, Steps Into a Big Fight Over a Small Road in Alaska
description: The legal battle over the gravel route could gut an environmental law that the 39th president called one of his highest achievements.
content: By Alaskan standards, the gravel road that an isolated community near the Aleutian Islands wants to build to connect to an airport is not a huge project. But because it would be cut through a federal wildlife refuge, the road has been a simmering source of contention since it was first proposed decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Resources for Talking and Teaching About the School Shooting in Uvalde, Texas
description: Using Times reporting and Opinion pieces, we offer teachers ideas and materials for addressing this tragedy in the classroom.
content: “The repetition of horror numbs the mind,” writes Thomas Fuller in a May 25 article, “The Stupefying Tally of American Gun Violence”:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Would John Eastman Want to Overturn an Election for Trump?
description: Why he was so eager to foment a constitutional crisis.
content: The figure of John Eastman, a constitutional theorist, former law professor and legal adviser to Donald Trump, looms increasingly large in retrospectives on the events of Jan. 6, and for good reason: Out of all the characters who floated through the White House in the aftermath of the 2020 election, only Eastman appears to have been fully serious about keeping Trump in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: ‘I am sick and tired of it. We have to act,’ Biden says.
description: A shaken and emotional President Biden declared that it is “time to turn this pain into action” as he addressed the nation following the slaughter of 18 elementary school children and a teacher in Texas.
content: WASHINGTON — A shaken and emotional President Biden declared that it is “time to turn this pain into action” Tuesday night as he addressed the nation following the slaughter of 18 elementary school children and a teacher in Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: ‘Quantum Internet’ Inches Closer With Advance in Data Teleportation
description: Scientists have improved their ability to send quantum information across distant computers — and have taken another step toward the network of the future.
content: From Santa Barbara, Calif., to Hefei, China, scientists are developing a new kind of computer that will make today’s machines look like toys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diana Buttu
title: Journalist Shireen Abu Akleh Was Killed in Jenin. Who Will Be Next?
description: A transparent investigation into the killing of Shireen Abu Akleh will lead to much-needed accountability.
content: I first met the pioneering Palestinian American journalist Shireen Abu Akleh more than two decades ago. She was in the early days of her career at Al Jazeera, and I was at the start of my stint as a legal adviser to the Palestine Liberation Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saikou Jammeh and Ruth Maclean
title: Gambia Says It Will Prosecute Former President for Murder
description: Victims of Yahya Jammeh, who ruled the West African country for 22 years, welcomed the announcement but said exactly how he will be brought to justice is not clear.
content: BANJUL, Gambia — Many of the Gambian citizens who testified in recent years that their former president was responsible for a wide range of atrocities never thought they would one day see him tried in a courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Sharks, Tattoos, Faces
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn why people tend to see faces in everyday objects, interpret an illustration of a high-wire act, read about changing attitudes toward tattoos in Japan, test their geography skills (using photos), and take a vocabulary quiz about free diving with sharks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: I Tried Apple’s Self-Repair Program With My iPhone. Disaster Ensued.
description: Apple’s do-it-yourself tools and instructions are far from ideal for most of us. I know this because I broke my phone trying to use them.
content: Apple last month released its first self-repair program that gives people access to the parts, tools and instructions to fix our own iPhones. It made waves when it was announced last year because it was a turning point for the right-to-repair movement, which has urged tech companies for more than a decade to provide resources so we can revive our electronics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings’ Review: A Life Too Simplified
description: This New York City Children’s Theater adaptation of Maya Angelou’s celebrated memoir faces the challenge of faithfully telling a story that encompasses a great deal of pain.
content: They were such tiny little kids to put on a train by themselves from Southern California to rural Arkansas — Maya Angelou only 3, her big brother, Bailey, all of 4. Each wore a wrist tag spelling out who they were, where they were headed and who would take care of them there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Chelsea Daniel, Robert Szypko, Michael Simon Johnson, Lisa Chow, Lisa Tobin, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Another Elementary School Massacre
description: What can the experience of some of the Sandy Hook parents tell us about what now awaits those who lost children in Uvalde, Texas?
content: This episode covers incidents of mass violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Latest Legionnaires’ Outbreak in the Bronx Kills 1 and Sickens 18
description: Health officials urged Bronx residents with flulike symptoms to seek medical care after Legionella bacteria were found in cooling towers there.
content: A growing cluster of Legionnaires’ disease cases in the Bronx has resulted in the death of one person and illness in 18 others, eight of whom are currently hospitalized, the New York City Health Department said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Katie Benner
title: School Shooting Casts a Pall Over Hearing for Biden’s Pick to Lead A.T.F.
description: Tuesday’s massacre shed a harsh light on the differences between a supporter of a renewed assault weapons ban and Republicans, who consider him a threat to Second Amendment rights.
content: WASHINGTON — The massacre in Texas cast a pall over confirmation hearings on Wednesday for Steven Dettelbach, President Biden’s pick to run the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, but it may have improved his chances of being confirmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Kate Moss Denies Johnny Depp Pushed Her Down Stairs in Testimony
description: Appearing as a witness for Mr. Depp, whom she dated in the 1990s, the British model countered testimony by the actor’s ex-wife, Amber Heard, who had alluded to a rumored incident between them.
content: Lawyers on each side of the defamation case between Johnny Depp and Amber Heard worked on Wednesday to undermine the credibility of the other as the trial wound down and the moment approached when the jury would be tasked with deciding whether to believe that Mr. Depp abused Ms. Heard, she abused him or mutual abuse occurred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: A City Under Fire
description: Russian forces pound Sievierodonetsk.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weekday guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Pennsylvania’s G.O.P. Senate primary is officially headed to a recount.
description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, backed by former President Donald J. Trump, was leading David McCormick by fewer than 1,000 votes in one of this year’s most closely watched contests.
content: The Republican primary for a Senate seat in Pennsylvania will go to a recount, with Dr. Mehmet Oz, the celebrity physician backed by former President Donald J. Trump, clinging to a narrow advantage over David McCormick, a former hedge fund executive, in one of the nation’s most intensely watched midterm contests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: The F.B.I. released a report showing a steep rise in ‘active’ shooters on Monday.
description: The annual total of shootings involving an attacker “attempting to kill people in a populated area” has nearly doubled since 2017.
content: The F.B.I. released alarming data showing a rapidly escalating pattern of public shootings in the United States on Monday, one day before the massacre in Uvalde, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allegra Goodman
title: The Siblings in This Book Loathe Each Other, and It’s So Refreshing
description: In “The Latecomer,” Jean Hanff Korelitz takes on complicated family dynamics, infidelity, race, class, religion, guilt, art and real estate.
content: Test tubes adorn the cover of “The Latecomer,” glassware signifying the in vitro origins of Jean Hanff Korelitz’s protagonists, the Oppenheimer triplets, Harrison, Lewyn and Sally. Our gifted narrator, who shall remain nameless so as not to spoil a wonderful twist, introduces us to these three, starting before conception — and explores their family tree (roots to branches). The result is a sparkling novel that is in essence satirical and wise, in style old and new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Katie Benner and Luke Broadwater
title: Intensifying Inquiry Into Alternate Electors Focuses on Trump Lawyers
description: In recent subpoenas, federal prosecutors investigating alternate slates of pro-Trump electors sought information about Rudolph W. Giuliani, John Eastman and others.
content: The Justice Department has stepped up its criminal investigation into the creation of alternate slates of pro-Trump electors seeking to overturn Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the 2020 election, with a particular focus on a team of lawyers that worked on behalf of President Donald J. Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: The Downing Street lockdown parties ‘represent a serious failure,’ a report says.
description: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson presided over a disorderly workplace in which there were widespread violations of coronavirus restrictions, according to a long-awaited government investigation released on Wednesday that is a moment of reckoning for the scandal-scarred British leader.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson presided over a disorderly workplace in which there were widespread violations of coronavirus restrictions, according to a long-awaited government investigation released on Wednesday that is a moment of reckoning for the scandal-scarred British leader.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: She Failed Penmanship as a Child. Now She’s a Successful Calligrapher.
description: “Our work is like preparing for a Broadway show that goes on for only one night.”
content: As a young girl, Ellen Weldon probably never dreamed she would grow up to become a calligrapher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Two top Republicans in the Michigan governor’s race face disqualification over forged petitions, officials say.
description: The Bureau of Elections moved to exclude James Craig and Perry Johnson from the primary ballot, finding that they had failed to collect the required signatures.
content: Two top Republican candidates for governor in Michigan are in danger of being denied a spot on the primary ballot after the state’s election bureau invalidated thousands of signatures submitted by their campaigns, saying many of the names had been forged and were collected by fraudulent petition circulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The U.S. budget deficit is projected to fall to $1 trillion in 2022.
description: The Congressional Budget Office provided an update on the path for deficits at a moment when the Federal Reserve is trying to cool the economy to tame rapid inflation.
content: WASHINGTON — The federal budget deficit is projected to decline sharply this year as spending on pandemic aid programs subsides and the economy continues to expand, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said in new forecasts released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Calls for Action After Texas Shooting, but Faces Limits of His Power
description: White House officials said the president was under no illusions that the Senate would pass gun safety legislation given continued opposition by Republicans.
content: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. responded to the slaughter of 20 elementary school children by declaring: “The world has changed, and it’s demanding action.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu
title: China pushes for regular mass testing in its ‘zero Covid’ pursuit.
description: The strategy risks increasing economic stress and trying people’s patience.
content: Chinese cities and provinces have turned to regular mass coronavirus testing, even in the absence of a local Covid-19 outbreak, raising concerns about the economic toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Marjorie Taylor Greene wins her primary, dashing establishment G.O.P. hopes.
description: The far-right congresswoman fended off a challenge from a Republican businesswoman who had hoped to push Ms. Greene into a runoff election.
content: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, whose far-right beliefs and confrontational behavior earned her opposition in both parties, won the Republican primary in her Northwest Georgia House district, beating a businesswoman who had garnered support among some in the G.O.P. establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Yarm
title: The All-Female Band Fanny Made History. A New Doc Illuminates It.
description: The group put out five albums in the ’70s and counted David Bowie and Bonnie Raitt as fans. The filmmaker Bobbi Jo Hart, dismayed its story hadn’t been told, took action.
content: In spring 2015, the documentary filmmaker Bobbi Jo Hart was clicking around the Taylor Guitars website, looking for a new instrument for her 10-year-old daughter, when she came across a short profile of June Millington, the singer and lead guitarist for the pioneering 1970s all-female rock group Fanny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Goodman
title: More details emerge on the gunman’s movement before the attack.
description: A law enforcement officer at the school exchanged gunfire with the gunman, but the gunman was able to get past the officer, a state police official said.
content: On Wednesday, new details emerged about the gunman’s movement ahead of the attack. The gunman shot his grandmother at her home less than a half-mile away from Robb Elementary School on Tuesday, according to preliminary investigatory documents described by a state police official. The woman, who survived but was wounded, made her way across the street to a neighbor’s home for help, the official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Hodara
title: Monroe, Conn.: A ‘Family-centric’ Community With a Small-Town Feel
description: The Fairfield County suburb offers ‘more house and space for a lot less money’ than neighboring towns like Fairfield and Westport.
content: Before Hurricane Sandy hit New York in 2012, life in a 200-square-foot East Village rental was already feeling cramped for Tessa Allison, Jim Wolf and their miniature schnauzer, Veruca Salt. But after they were left without heat and hot water for weeks, Ms. Allison said, “We were like, ‘This is too much. Let’s get out of here.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Han
title: How I Learned to Live With Ghosts
description: The Korean tradition of jesa, or memorializing ancestors, helped me understand that our loved ones continue to shape our lives long after they have departed.
content: According to my paternal grandmother, I’ve always been receptive to spirits. She likes to remind me how I would wake her up in the middle of the night, hyperventilating as I tried to explain that my spirit had left my body, that I had found my nose pressed against the ceiling as I hovered above my bed; that I had lost my eyes and couldn’t see. Back in my body, I rubbed my arms and wrapped them around my legs, not sure if I had actually returned. For many nights, I continued to jolt awake, crashing back into my body as if dropped from a great height.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: The Stupefying Tally of American Gun Violence
description: An attack at a Buffalo supermarket. A California church pierced by gunfire. And now 19 elementary school students killed in Uvalde, Texas.
content: The repetition of horror numbs the mind: Only 11 days ago there was Buffalo, with a man driven by racism gunning down 10 people at a supermarket. The next day another angry man walked into a Presbyterian church in Laguna Woods, Calif., and killed one person and wounded five others. And now, Uvalde, Texas — a repeat of what was once thought unfathomable: the killing of at least 19 elementary school children in second, third and fourth grades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: F.D.A. Chief Details ‘Shocking’ Conditions at Baby Formula Plant
description: Agency inspectors found a leaking roof, standing water and cracked production equipment before a facility shutdown that led to major shortages.
content: The Abbott Nutrition plant in Michigan that was shut down in February, sparking a widespread baby formula shortage crisis, had a leaking roof, water pooled on the floor and cracks in key production equipment that allowed bacteria to get in and persist, Dr. Robert Califf, the head of the Food and Drug Administration, told a House panel on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu, Sheera Frenkel and Stuart A. Thompson
title: Debunking 3 Viral Rumors About the Texas Shooting
description: False and unfounded claims started to spread online shortly after the killings.
content: Rumors about the gunman and what had taken place spread widely online — often with easily debunked evidence or none at all — almost immediately after the first official reports about the deadly school shooting in Uvalde, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Fed officials expected to make at least three big rate increases over the next few months.
description: Minutes of the Federal Reserve’s May meeting underscored the deep concern within the central bank about rapidly rising prices that have far exceeded the Fed’s target.
content: Federal Reserve officials agreed at their last meeting that the central bank needed to move “expeditiously” to bring down the most rapid pace of inflation in 40 years, with most participants expecting as many as three half-a-percentage-point interest rate increases in the months ahead, minutes of the Fed’s May meeting showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: A Big Baritone Sound at Play in an Intimate Setting
description: Justin Austin’s program in the Board of Officers Room at the Armory included three cycles of Langston Hughes poems.
content: In a program of songs highlighting a broad range of American compositional voices — Black, gay, female, old, new — the baritone Justin Austin showed off a mighty lyric voice with dramatic flair at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan on Tuesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A teacher who was killed cared for her students like her own children.
description: Grieving family members have begun to share the names of the victims from Tuesday’s shooting. Police officers have yet to release a list.
content: Irma Garcia, a teacher of more than two decades, was known as a steadfast optimist in her family. She would crack jokes at gatherings in Uvalde, Texas, sing her favorite classic rock tunes during parties and help her nephew, John Martinez, with homework.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: An Oliver Sacks Book Becomes an Opera, With Help From Friends
description: Tobias Picker and Aryeh Lev Stollman have adapted “Awakenings,” drawing both on source material and personal experience.
content: “These are all cycads,” the composer Tobias Picker said, gesturing at a low canopy of fanned-out, pinnate leaves near the entrance of the conservatory at the New York Botanical Garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Approves New Water Restrictions Amid Worsening Drought
description: The regulations are the strictest statewide mandates yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Discrimination Weakens Tool for Reducing N.Y. Homelessness, Lawsuit Says
description: Vouchers, which help people afford rent, have long been seen as a key to solving the nation’s housing woes. But in New York City, a broken oversight system is undermining their effectiveness, advocates say.
content: A voucher program designed to reduce homelessness in New York City has been hamstrung by the discriminatory practices of landlords and real estate agents who have turned away people relying on subsidies to pay rent, according to a lawsuit filed on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Brian Jackson, a Key Gil Scott-Heron Collaborator, Reintroduces Himself
description: For a decade, Jackson was the revolutionary artist and activist’s musical director. After their split, and 35 years in a day job, he is finding his way back with a new album.
content: The sun was beaming down on a backyard in southern France one recent afternoon as the pianist, flutist, vocalist and composer Brian Jackson answered a video call on his phone, preparing to do something that, until recently, he hadn’t done in decades: take questions from a journalist about his new album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Speeds Up Reshaping of Taiwan’s Defenses to Deter China
description: The Biden administration is taking lessons from the war in Ukraine to turn Taiwan into a “porcupine” bristling with weapons that would inflict severe pain if attacked.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has accelerated its efforts to reshape Taiwan’s defense systems as it projects a more robust American military presence in the region to try to deter a potential attack by the Chinese military, current and former U.S. officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $700,000 Homes in Maryland, Iowa and Massachusetts
description: A 1750 Colonial in Chestertown, a midcentury-modern showplace in West Des Moines and a Cape Cod cottage in East Sandwich.
content: Chestertown, on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, is a popular second-home destination for residents of a number of Mid-Atlantic cities. This house is one of the contributing buildings in the town’s historic district, along with several other Colonial-era homes. It is a few blocks from the Chester River, in a bustling area with a bookstore, a luncheonette and a tavern that serves afternoon tea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Who Is Austin Butler and What Does He Want?
description: Hollywood thinks he might be the next big star. But with the risky “Elvis” riding on his performance, the magnetic actor is feeling the pressure.
content: “Are you ready to fly?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina Chocano
title: Why Is ‘Bob’s Burgers’ So Freakishly Lovable? This Guy.
description: Loren Bouchard’s accidental career as a comedy mogul has now brought his TV family to the big screen.
content: Sometimes Loren Bouchard thinks about how close he came to having a totally different life from the one he has now — one that would not exist if he hadn’t bumped into his elementary-school science teacher in Harvard Square one day in 1993.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Josh Duggar Is Sentenced to 12 Years for Downloading Images of Child Sex Abuse
description: Mr. Duggar, 34, a former star of the TLC reality show “19 Kids and Counting,” was convicted in December after he tried to covertly download graphic images to his computer in Arkansas.
content: Josh Duggar, a onetime star of the TLC reality show “19 Kids and Counting,” about a large family guided by conservative Christian values, was sentenced to more than 12 years in prison on Wednesday for downloading child sexual abuse imagery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Ideas Do You Have to Bring Your Community Closer Together?
description: New York City’s Open Streets program is designing new places for residents to gather. Does your community need more public spaces?
content: Do you feel connected to the people in your community? Does your town offer public spaces for people to meet and hang out? Do you wish it had more?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: After Texas Shooting, Ted Cruz Digs In Against Gun Control
description: After the mass shooting at an elementary school in his home state, the senator called for armed law enforcement on campuses and faulted Democrats for politicizing the issue.
content: WASHINGTON — Hours after the worst school shooting in a decade took place in his home state, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas acknowledged that there were “way too many of these horrific mass murders” and suggested a possible solution: putting armed law enforcement on campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jocelyn Benson
title: An Angry Crowd Came to My House. I Still Support the Right to Protest.
description: Despite the terrifying experience of armed protesters picketing Jocelyn Benson’s house, she supports the right to protest outside public officials’ homes.
content: It was close to 9 p.m. on a Saturday in early December of 2020. My son, then age 4, and I were putting the finishing touches on our Christmas tree as “How the Grinch Stole Christmas” played in the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: An Opera About Harvey Milk Finally Finds Itself
description: The composer Stewart Wallace has overhauled his 1990s score and says “the music is freer now, and more organic, and yet completely recognizable.”
content: When he composed “Harvey Milk,” in the early 1990s, Stewart Wallace was adding to a string of much discussed “biopic” operas based on recent history. Philip Glass’s “Satyagraha,” about Gandhi; Anthony Davis’s “X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X”; and John Adams’s “Nixon in China” were still fresh in people’s ears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Imam
title: In a Former Mafia Stronghold, Art Remembers, and Warns
description: A public art campaign in Palermo, Sicily, is reminding residents of the city’s grim Mafia years, and is encouraging them to resist creeping organized crime influence.
content: PALERMO, Sicily — Until recently, this city was infamous as one of the world’s organized crime capitals. Warring mobsters gunned down rivals in the streets and built ugly high-rise apartments with public funds while much of the historic center was left to crumble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: After Mass Gun Killings, Other Nations Changed Course — to Notable Effect
description: Britain, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Norway: All had a culture of gun ownership, and all tightened restrictions anyway. Their violence statistics now diverge sharply from those of the U.S.
content: The world over, mass shootings are frequently met with a common response: Officials impose new restrictions on gun ownership. Mass shootings become rarer. Homicides and suicides tend to decrease, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Summer in the City Is Back (Again!)
description: And this year, we made a bucket list to get you started.
content: Welcome back to Summer in the City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: At Least Trump Didn’t Get What He Wanted This Week
description: When everything seems awful, one little ray of sun …
content: Well, the people have spoken. Sort of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Lola Fadulu
title: Parents Face a Haunting Question: Is Any Schoolchild Safe?
description: A day after the massacre in Uvalde, Tex., parents and caregivers agonized over the safety of America’s children.
content: Late Tuesday night, Luz Belliard sat on the edge of her bed in Upper Manhattan in the room she shares with her 9-year-old granddaughter, Victoria, and thought about what to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
title: Johnson Says He’s Humbled by ‘Partygate’ Report but Will Go On
description: The long-awaited report on boozy parties that violated lockdown rules was once seen as potentially ruinous for Prime Minister Boris Johnson, but the situation has changed.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson presided over a disorderly workplace in which there were rampant violations of coronavirus restrictions, according to a long-awaited government investigation, released on Wednesday, that became a moment of reckoning for the scandal-scarred British leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Parents were asked for DNA samples to help identify victims.
description: DNA testing is more accurate, according to a medical examiner, but it also spares parents the trauma of having to view photos.
content: Among the countless chilling details to emerge from the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, on Tuesday was this: The authorities had asked parents waiting in agony for news about their children to give DNA samples.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Ana Ley, Ashley Wong and Patrick McGeehan
title: Q Train Killing Threatens Subway’s Fragile Comeback
description: The subway is at a critical moment as transit officials struggle to bring back riders, to shore up the system’s finances and to address fears over safety.
content: Transit officials in New York City celebrated a major milestone last week: The subway system logged 3.6 million trips in a single day, a pandemic-era record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber
title: Subway Killing Suspect Told Riders to Put Phones Away, Prosecutor Says
description: After Andrew Abdullah fatally shot a Q train passenger, others in the same car feared they would be next, a prosecutor told a judge on Wednesday.
content: A Brooklyn man charged in the unprovoked killing of a Q train rider last weekend instructed other passengers to “put their cellphones away” after the fatal shooting, a Manhattan prosecutor told a judge on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Dozens of Migrants Die After Boat Sinks Off Tunisian Coast
description: The vessel carried about 100 people and had left from a Libyan port city.
content: Seventy-six migrants were presumed dead after their boat, which departed from Libya, sank off the coast of Tunisia, the United Nations migration agency said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: germinal
description: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word germinal has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 21 in “Got a Covid Booster? You Probably Won’t Need Another for a Long Time” by Apoorva Mandavilli:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The Texas gunman texted a friend that he had shot his grandmother and was about to ‘shoot up’ a school.
description: A 15-year-old girl in Germany said in an interview that she had met the future gunman about two weeks earlier on Yubo, an app that lets people livestream themselves to strangers.
content: The gunman who killed 19 children and two adults at a school in Uvalde, Texas, told an online acquaintance that he had just shot his grandmother and was about to “shoot up a elementary school” minutes before carrying out one of the deadliest school shootings in United States history, according to screenshots provided by the friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Morton L. Janklow, Agent for Best-Selling Authors, Dies at 91
description: A bold, risk-taking negotiator, he numbered among his clients Danielle Steel, Judith Krantz, three presidents and Pope John Paul II.
content: Morton L. Janklow, the storied New York literary agent who struck megadeals with publishers for best-selling authors, ghostwritten celebrities, several presidents and a pope, and who influenced international book lists and the reading habits of millions for decades, died on Wednesday at his home in Water Mill, N.Y. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The Real Death Toll
description: Globally, about 13 percent more people died than expected in the first two years of the pandemic.
content: Throughout the pandemic, the U.S. has had outsize access to lifesaving supplies like vaccines, antiviral treatments, face masks and testing kits. The country has also spent trillions of dollars in pandemic stimulus funds and enacted a raft of policies at the local and national level to combat the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why Trillium Have Become the Poster Child for Endangered Native Plants
description: According to a recent report, many of these ‘charismatic’ wildflowers are threatened with extinction. Here’s what you can do to help.
content: That good things come in threes was a lesson I learned in stages. It began years ago, when I bought my house in the Hudson Valley and noticed three tiny plants growing under the edge of the front porch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Two High Seeds Need Five-Set Thrillers to Win at French Open
description: Alexander Zverev and Carlos Alcaraz saved match points in the men’s singles tournament before turning things around.
content: PARIS — The thrills were separated only by a short stroll through the formal gardens at the French Open on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Man in Custody in ‘Every New Yorker’s Worst Nightmare’
description: Andrew Abdullah, 25, the suspect in the fatal shooting on the Q train, had a history of arrests in gun offenses.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll follow the surrender of the suspect in Sunday’s subway shooting. We’ll also look at Jewish soldiers from World War II who had Christian burials. They’re now getting appropriate religious ceremonies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Rainbow Cocktails to Magical Beasts
description: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: THE FOUR AGES OF AMERICAN FOREIGN POLICY: Weak Power, Great Power, Superpower, Hyperpower, by Michael Mandelbaum. (Oxford University, $34.95.) Mandelbaum, a leading foreign policy expert, presents a new framework for understanding how the United States’ foreign policy and global might have changed since the country’s inception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: 7 Million Bad Student Loans With No Way Out, for Anyone
description: The Biden administration plans to offer those with loans in default a fresh start. It would help borrowers and the government alike.
content: With 45 million borrowers owing it a total of $1.6 trillion, the federal Education Department is effectively America’s largest consumer bank. And like any bank, it sees some of its loans go bad when borrowers can’t pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: How to Help Victims of the Uvalde School Shooting
description: Some local medical centers encouraged blood donations, while at least one legal organization was seeking volunteer attorneys licensed in Texas.
content: On Tuesday, an 18-year-old gunman opened fire at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, a rural town about 80 miles west of San Antonio, killing 19 children and two teachers, and wounding several other children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: These Gun Reforms Could Save 15,000 Lives. We Can Achieve Them.
description: What we’re doing on guns isn’t working. We need new approaches.
content: Gun enthusiasts protest that now is the time for mourning, not politics, for national grief rather than polarizing debates about firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Said to Have Reacted Approvingly to Jan. 6 Chants About Hanging Pence
description: The House committee investigating the Capitol assault has heard accounts of the former president’s remarks as he watched the riot unfold on television.
content: Shortly after hundreds of rioters at the Capitol started chanting “Hang Mike Pence!” on Jan. 6, 2021, the White House chief of staff, Mark Meadows, left the dining room off the Oval Office, walked into his own office and told colleagues that President Donald J. Trump was complaining that the vice president was being whisked to safety.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Join Us for Closing the Gap on Climate Inequity, a Times Virtual Event on Climate Change
description: The global south contributes little to climate change yet suffers disproportionately from its effects. Join New York Times journalists and leading experts as they share their visions for an equitable, climate-resilient future.
content: Climate change affects us all, but that doesn’t mean we feel its effects equally. The countries that have contributed least to climate change are often the most exposed to its consequences. With the global south disproportionately paying the price for the global north’s excesses, what obligations does the rich world have to its more vulnerable neighbors? What could redress look like in practice and what would its practical implications be? What role can businesses, institutions and policymakers play in closing climate’s economic and social divides? Who will lead the charge?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Azi Paybarah and Leah Askarinam
title: In More Than 100 G.O.P. Midterm Ads This Year: Guns, Guns, Guns
description: For Republicans, brandishing firepower is a visual shorthand for hard-core conservatism. Democrats see little gain in highlighting an issue on which their party hasn’t been able to get much done.
content: In Alabama, Gov. Kay Ivey unpacked lipstick, an iPhone and something else from her purse in one campaign advertisement — “a little Smith & Wesson .38,” she said. A Republican candidate for governor in Georgia declared in a different spot, “I believe in Jesus, guns and babies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Itsy-Bitsy Bit
description: Christopher Youngs’s puzzle might induce delirium.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s a welcome return for the constructor, Christopher Youngs, who is making his second Wednesday puzzle appearance in the New York Times Crossword, following his debut in November. I’m not saying there’s a pattern here — I think that would require a third Wednesday — but I think two midweek puzzles feels like more than a coincidence for Mr. Youngs, who has crafted a pair of puzzles perfectly pitched to midweek difficulty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Lynsey Chutel
title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Texas School Shooting
description: Plus Russia’s narrowed focus and diplomacy in Africa.
content: Nineteen children and two teachers were killed on Tuesday in a single classroom at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas. Officers fatally shot the 18-year-old gunman at the scene. Here are live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: In the U.S., Backlash to Civil Rights Era Made Guns a Political Third Rail
description: Other countries changed course after massacres. But American political protection for guns is unique, and has become inseparable from conservative credentials.
content: I am a mother of two young children, and I wish I could say that the pain that parents in Uvalde, Texas, feel this morning is unimaginable to me. But the truth is it that although I have never experienced it directly, I have had to imagine that pain many times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Tallerico
title: ‘The Bob’s Burgers Movie’ Is Coming. Here Are 10 Great Episodes.
description: Need a primer or refresher before the movie debuts? These are the essential “Bob’s Burgers” episodes to watch.
content: The Fox animated sitcom “Bob’s Burgers” concluded its 12th season on Sunday, but fans, fear not: “The Bob’s Burgers Movie” debuts on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: An Age-by-Age Guide to Talking to Children About Mass Shootings
description: Whether you’ve got a kindergartner or a teenager, here is how to help them in the immediate aftermath of tragedy.
content: A devastating reality of raising children in America today is that parents must be prepared to talk to their kids about mass shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Who Decides the Right Way to Protest?
description: A debate on what it means to voice dissent, and how to tell whether it’s made a difference.
content: Two years ago, the murder of George Floyd sparked protests across America, gathering an estimated 15 million people into the streets during the summer of 2020. Since then, Americans of all political persuasions have taken to the streets to make their views known, on everything from mask mandates to abortion rights. But did protesting result in any real change? And looking back, where does that moment of collective outrage fit in the broader history of dissent in America?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Have School Shootings Shaped Your Experience as a Student?
description: The massacre at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, contributes to a grim history of school shootings in the U.S. What has it been like to attend school in the shadow of this violence?
content: The massacre that took place on Tuesday at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, was at least the 188th mass shooting at a school in the United States since 1970.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Gun makers’ stocks, which often rise after mass shootings, jump.
description: After shootings, investors often anticipate appeals for tighter gun laws and an increase in sales.
content: The share prices of gun and ammunition companies often rise after mass shootings, with investors anticipating a spike in sales ahead of calls for stricter gun laws. On Wednesday, the day after a deadly shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, prices for major gun-related stocks rose after a subdued start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moises Velasquez-Manoff
title: The Anti-Vaccine Movement’s New Frontier
description: A wave of parents has been radicalized by Covid-era misinformation to reject ordinary childhood immunizations — with potentially lethal consequences.
content: The mother of four brought her children, ranging in age from grade school to high school, to the doctor’s office last summer for their annual checkup. When their pediatrician, Robert Froehlke, said that it was time for shots and several boosters and then mentioned the Covid vaccine, her reaction stunned him. “I’m not going to kill my children,” Froehlke recalls her saying, as she began to shake and weep. He ushered her out of the examination room, away from her children, and tried to calm her. “We’re just trying to help your kids be healthy,” he told her. But he didn’t press the issue; he sensed that she wasn’t persuadable at that moment. And he didn’t want to drive her away from his practice altogether. “That really shook me up,” he says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Last Night,’ ‘Take This Waltz’ and More Streaming Gems
description: A handful of pointed indie dramas are among the highlights of this month’s off-the-radar streaming picks, as well as a funny werewolf movie and a Robin Williams comedy.
content: With the “Avatar” sequels finally, finally, finally heading our way, it’s worth remembering that innocent time when it looked like Sam Worthington was going to be a movie star. There’s a compelling case to be found in Massy Tadjedin’s four-hander, which is something of a mini-“Eyes Wide Shut” — a thoughtful marital drama that candidly explores the frustrations and temptations of long-term adult relationships. Worthington nicely underplays what amounts to the Tom Cruise role, but the eye-opener here is Keira Knightley, whose scorching turn as his frustrated wife reminds us that she’s just as compelling in contemporary roles as period pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: China Seeks Sweeping Regional Deal With Pacific Island Countries
description: Newly obtained documents shed light on how Beijing hopes to win friends and gain influence in an area of strategic importance.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — China is pursuing a regional agreement with Pacific island nations that would expand Beijing’s role in policing, maritime cooperation and cybersecurity while offering scholarships for more than 2,000 workers and young diplomats, according to documents obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary B. McCord
title: Uvalde, Buffalo and the Semiautomatic Weapons That Terrorize Us
description: The U.S. should treat easy access to semiautomatic weapons as a national security threat.
content: Within the past two weeks, the country saw the two deadliest mass shootings of the year, which authorities say were both committed by 18-year-olds using semiautomatic firearms. The motive for Tuesday’s attack on elementary school children in Uvalde, Texas, is still unknown. But the motive for the Buffalo attack appears clear from the online screed left by the shooting suspect. Influenced by the so-called great replacement theory, he sought to kill as many Black people as he could. Ten died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: An Exhibition on Cancer Puts Hope for the Future on Display
description: A history of the disease’s treatment, from gory past techniques to promising advances, is on show at the Science Museum in London.
content: LONDON — With so many lives affected by cancer — in the United States alone, about 40 percent will receive a cancer diagnosis during their lives — it might be understandable if the disease were a common and compelling subject for museum shows.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the full report.
description: Sue Gray’s inquiry into illicit lockdown parties in Downing Street was released on Wednesday.
content: An investigation released on Wednesday found that Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s office frequently violated Britain’s coronavirus restrictions, adding to pressure on his government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: A Heat Wave’s Lamented Victim: The Mango, India’s King of Fruits
description: Blistering spring temperatures have devastated crops of the country’s most beloved fruit. “The soul of a farmer shudders at seeing these fruitless trees,” one grower said.
content: MALIHABAD, India — No fruit in India is as universally loved and as eagerly anticipated as the mango, which, for one brief window each year, cools and sweetens the long days of summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa, J. David Goodman, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Julie Bosman
title: Deadliest U.S. School Shooting in Decade Shakes Rural Texas Town
description: UVALDE, Texas — The gunman who killed 19 children and two teachers in a rural Texas elementary school on Tuesday entered the building despite being confronted by an armed school security officer, then wounded two responding police officers and engaged in a standoff inside the school for over an hour, state police officials said.
content: UVALDE, Texas — The gunman who killed 19 children and two teachers in a rural Texas elementary school on Tuesday entered the building despite being confronted by an armed school security officer, then wounded two responding police officers and engaged in a standoff inside the school for over an hour, state police officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Jon Gruden’s Lawsuit Against the N.F.L. Can Proceed in Open Court
description: A Nevada judge dismissed the league’s motion to move the case to arbitration. Gruden, the former Raiders coach, claims that the N.F.L. leaked disparaging emails that led him to resign in October.
content: Jon Gruden won two important battles in his civil suit against the N.F.L. on Wednesday when a judge in Clark County, Nev., denied two of the league’s legal motions — one to dismiss his lawsuit outright and the other to compel a closed-door arbitration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Boeing’s Starliner Lands on Earth After Test Flight to Space Station
description: The largely successful journey of the capsule could set up a flight for NASA with astronauts aboard before the year’s end.
content: Boeing’s Starliner spacecraft returned to Earth on Wednesday after a largely successful uncrewed test flight that included four and a half days docked at the International Space Station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in Spain: A Restored Flour Mill Near Valencia for $105,000
description: Spain’s Teruel province has some of the country’s most affordable real estate, but agents say this was the busiest March for sales since 2007.
content: Tucked into the remote hills of Aragón, an autonomous community in northeastern Spain, this converted 17th-century flour mill is now a quaint country residence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: It Shouldn’t Take This Long to Vaccinate Our Youngest Kids
description: The formula shortage came on the heels of this seemingly endless wait.
content: The Food and Drug Administration last week announced authorization of a third Covid vaccine dose — a single booster — for children 5-11. This comes as parents of kids under 5 still wait for vaccine authorization for their children, after months of hard-to-decipher announcements, from both the F.D.A. and pharmaceutical companies. According to reporting from Sharon LaFraniere in The Times at the end of April, the F.D.A. said that it understood the urgency of protecting children under 5, “and that it would act quickly ‘if the data support a clear path forward following our evaluation.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Emma Bubola
title: ‘Not Again’: A Weary Europe Greets Monkeypox With a Touch of Fatalism
description: With war raging in Ukraine, and the coronavirus still circulating, many in Europe say they have bigger worries than monkeypox. Some organizations, however, have raised concerns about stigma.
content: LONDON — With the cost of living soaring, a devastating war in Ukraine and the coronavirus still circulating, many Europeans had already been feeling anxious and drained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
title: Israel Tells U.S. It Killed Iranian Officer, Official Says
description: Israeli officials say the officer, Sayad Khodayee, was a leader of a covert unit tasked with abductions and killings of Israelis and other foreigners around the world. Iran does not acknowledge that the unit exists.
content: At the funeral in Tehran for a colonel in Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps, thousands of mourners packed the streets around the cemetery chanting “Death to Israel” and calling for revenge for his killing.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Welcome to the world of Bayesian persuasion.
content: Tommy James & the Shondells sang “Crystal Blue Persuasion.” Economists have their own shade of persuasion — Bayesian.
source.name: The New York Times

title: We Can’t Even Agree on What Is Tearing Us Apart
description: Even scholars of polarization are polarized.
content: Today, even scholars of polarization are polarized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger, David McCabe and Anupreeta Das
title: Twitter is fined $150 million in privacy settlement, as Elon Musk commits more equity to fund deal.
description: Twitter did not do enough to tell its users that the personal data it had collected was used partly to help marketers target ads, the F.T.C. and Justice Department said.
content: Twitter was fined $150 million by the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department on Wednesday, as part of a settlement for misleading users about how it treated their personal data.

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: In Texas, lenient gun laws are woven into the fabric of the state.
description: Texas has long had some of the least-restrictive gun laws in the United States, priding itself as a state with responsible gun owners, even with its recent history of mass shootings.
content: Texas has long had some of the least-restrictive gun laws in the United States, priding itself as a state with responsible gun owners — more than a million — even with its recent history of mass shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin visits the wounded at a military hospital in Moscow, in a first since the Ukraine invasion.
description: The Russian leader also announces new social welfare measures and military benefits in an apparent effort to show Russians he is aware times are tough.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin visited wounded soldiers on Wednesday and announced a raft of new social welfare measures and military benefits — an apparent effort to show Russians that he was aware times were tough as the war in Ukraine entered its fourth month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Who won, who lost and what was too close to call on Tuesday.
description: Here is a rundown of what happened in some of the most important contests in Georgia, Alabama, Arkansas and Texas.
content: Ever since former President Donald J. Trump lost in the state of Georgia during the 2020 presidential election, he has sought revenge against the Republican incumbents there whom he blamed for not helping him overturn the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: ‘How to Murder Your Husband’ Writer Convicted of Murdering Husband
description: Nancy Brophy, a 71-year-old romance novelist, was accused in the shooting death of her husband. She said prosecutors had sketched a flawed plotline.
content: A romance novelist who wrote about “How to Murder Your Husband” was convicted in her husband’s killing on Wednesday following a contentious trial in which prosecutors leaned on a “puzzle” of circumstantial evidence to portray the author as a duplicitous spouse who spent months quietly plotting the perfect crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Martin
title: Thomas S. Murphy, Broadcasting ‘Minnow’ Who Swallowed ABC, Dies at 96
description: As the head of Capital Cities Communications, he engineered the acquisition of the TV giant. He later sold the company to Disney, at a huge profit.
content: Thomas S. Murphy, who as chairman and chief executive of Capital Cities Communications stunned Wall Street in 1985 by acquiring the much larger American Broadcasting Company for $3.5 billion, then 10 years later startled Wall Street again by selling the resultant company to Disney for $19 billion, died on Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: How (and Why) We Calculated the Value of Haiti’s Payments to France
description: We wanted to know how much Haiti had paid over generations. So we set out to compile the data.
content: Last June, when we were well into our investigation into Haiti’s payments to their former French slave masters, our trail seemed to be diverging in a thousand directions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Administration, Settling a Long Feud, Moves to Block a Mine in Alaska
description: The E.P.A. has proposed to ban the disposal of mining waste in the Bristol Bay watershed, a decision that very likely means the end of the Pebble Mine project.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Wednesday took a major legal step toward protecting Bristol Bay in Alaska, one of the world’s most valuable sockeye salmon fisheries that also sits atop enormous copper and gold deposits long coveted by mining companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: 19 Murdered Children
description: Gun violence has killed more children and destroyed another community.
content: Nineteen children were murdered in Uvalde, Texas, yesterday. They were elementary school students, attending their last week of classes before summer vacation, when an 18-year-old gunman came through the door and began shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Raffensperger fends off a 2020 election denier to win Georgia’s G.O.P. secretary of state primary.
description: He promoted himself as a champion of “election integrity” and rebutted falsehoods made by Donald Trump and his allies.
content: Brad Raffensperger, the Georgia Republican official who famously rebuffed former President Donald J. Trump’s requests to “find” enough votes to help him overturn the 2020 election, defeated a Republican primary challenge on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Some universities and schools in the U.S. are reimposing indoor mask mandates.
description: The moves are a sign that while the academic year may be coming to a close, the pandemic is still not.
content: As coronavirus cases have increased across the United States, some universities and public school systems have reimposed indoor mask mandates on their campuses, a sign that while the academic year may be coming to a close, the pandemic is still not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats Hit Pause on Gun Control Vote, Hoping for a Compromise
description: After the deadliest school shooting in a decade, the top Senate Democrat said he would wait to force a vote on gun safety measures the G.O.P. has opposed.
content: WASHINGTON — Just shy of a decade after the Senate’s failure to respond to the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Democrats are again trying to transform outrage over the gun deaths of children into action by Congress to curb gun violence in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Unlikely Ascent of New York’s Compost Champion’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the environmental work led by Domingo Morales. Then, they will research and come up with a plan for one climate action they can take in their community.
content: Featured Article: “The Unlikely Ascent of New York’s Compost Champion” by Cara Buckley
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: A New Jersey Republican’s Political Strategy: Say Less
description: Ahead of next month’s primary, Tom Kean Jr., running in New Jersey’s most competitive House race, hopes to avoid alienating moderate swing voters while facing challengers from the right.
content: Tom Kean Jr., a New Jersey Republican locked in the state’s most competitive congressional race, has refused to debate his primary opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Her Tennis Coach Abused Her. Could the Sport Have Prevented It?
description: Adrienne Jensen does not know Pam Shriver, the 22-time Grand Slam doubles champion, but both believe tennis needs to change its approach toward predatory coaches.
content: The grooming of Adrienne Jensen began with an invitation to train with a top junior tennis coach at a well-regarded tennis academy in suburban Kansas City in 2009.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Responding to the Shooting in Uvalde
description: A place for young people to express their thoughts and feelings.
content: A gunman opened fire at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, on Tuesday, killing 19 children and two adults, in the deadliest shooting at an elementary school since the devastating attack at Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Conn., in 2012.
source.name: The New York Times
