title: What to Know About the School Shooting in Uvalde, Texas
description: Nineteen children and two teachers were killed in a massacre at an elementary school. It was the deadliest school shooting in the United States in a decade.
content: Read the latest about the deadly school shooting in Uvalde, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Glenn Thrush
title: Beto O’Rourke interrupts a news conference by his opponent, Gov. Greg Abbott, accusing him of ‘doing nothing.’
description: The former congressman shouted that the elementary school killings were a “totally predictable” result of lax state and federal gun laws.
content: Former Representative Beto O’Rourke interrupted a news conference held by Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Wednesday to accuse Republicans of “doing nothing” to address gun violence in the aftermath of a shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: Trisha Brown’s Mischief, Mystery and Delicate Aberrations
description: In a delayed celebration of its 50th anniversary, the Brown company presented two dazzling works she made with Robert Rauschenberg.
content: The dancer Cecily Campbell is alone onstage when you begin to hear it: the faint sound of a marching band floating through the silence. Is it the ordinary commotion of New York City, on the street outside the theater, or part of the dance?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Tim Arango
title: In Minneapolis, Overhaul Efforts Stall as Police Resist Change
description: The two years after the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis officer have seen a raft of policy changes, but many residents say that genuine change has been slow.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — It was a searing example of a police department hitting rock bottom: a veteran police officer murdered George Floyd, a Black man, on a busy street in broad daylight and set off racial justice protests around the globe. Minneapolis promised to set an example. “Changing the world starts here,” Mayor Jacob Frey wrote in an opinion essay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Adam Pasick, David F. Gallagher and Jenny Gross
title: Guns, Law and the Uvalde Elementary School Shooting
description: This could be the mass shooting that leads to significant change — or it could join the long list of other atrocities that have been followed by policy stalemates.
content: The horrific school shooting yesterday in Uvalde, Texas, has ramped up the intensity of the national debate over gun control and the emotions around it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyon
title: After Pandemic Delays, a New Dilemma: Disinviting Wedding Guests
description: Revoking invitations can at the very least be awkward and, at most, be seen as a major faux pas. But that hasn’t stopped couples from doing so to have celebrations on their terms.
content: Brissa Ortega and Devin Joll haven’t decided on the best way to inform some 35 of their friends, relatives and co-workers that they are no longer invited to the couple’s wedding in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Charlie Savage
title: Defense Team for Democratic-Linked Lawyer Won’t Call Ex-Times Reporter to Testify
description: Lawyers had argued that the reporter, Eric Lichtblau, should testify about his communications with their client, Michael Sussmann, who is accused of lying to the F.B.I.
content: WASHINGTON — The defense team for Michael Sussmann, a lawyer with ties to Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign, has dropped its plans to call a former New York Times reporter to testify in a trial that centers on Mr. Sussmann’s motives in meeting with the F.B.I. in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Glimmerglass Festival Names a New Director
description: Robert Ainsley, a champion of new American opera, takes the reins from Francesca Zambello. He said the festival would continue to showcase work that tells “everyone’s story.”
content: The Glimmerglass Festival in Cooperstown, N.Y., announced on Wednesday that it has named Robert Ainsley as it next artistic and general director, giving the festival a new leader as it moves toward its 50th season, in 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Joe Pignatano, Met Coach Known for His Bullpen Farm, Dies at 92
description: After an undistinguished career as a catcher with the Brooklyn Dodgers and other teams, he cultivated vegetables as well as relief pitchers at Shea Stadium.
content: Joe Pignatano, who was a reserve catcher with four major league teams, including the Brooklyn Dodgers, but gained his greatest renown for cultivating a vegetable garden at Shea Stadium when he was the Mets’ bullpen coach, died on Monday in Naples, Fla. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Haitian President Demands Reparations and Ends Up in Exile
description: Quotation of the Day, for Wednesday, May 25, 2022
content: “What I think we will never forgive Haiti for, deep down, is that it is the country that beat us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Julie Beckett, Who Helped Disabled Children Live at Home, Dies at 72
description: A waiver named for her daughter, Katie, has allowed hundreds of thousands of children to receive medical care without having to live in a hospital.
content: Julie Beckett, who with her daughter, Katie, pushed for changes to Medicaid that enabled hundreds of thousands of families to raise and care for their disabled children at home, died on May 13 in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. She was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett
title: A Doomed River Crossing Shows the Perils of Entrapment in the War’s East
description: Encirclement is a tactic used by both sides in the war between Russia and Ukraine, but it can carry big risks.
content: BILOHORIVKA, Ukraine — Out on the riverbank, the scene of mayhem unfolded under a baking spring sun: blown-up tanks, the detritus of pontoon bridges, heaps of branches shorn off by explosions and the bodies of Russian soldiers, some half buried in the mud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: Biscotti So Good They Made Me Cry
description: These chocolate biscotti, spiked with chiles and studded with cashews, possess the power to persuade even the staunchest doubters.
content: The package arrived, unbidden, two days into New York City’s lockdown in March 2020. We were adapting to our new life, prowling through the apartment at all hours. I was trying to figure out how to hand-stitch masks using old jeans and shoelaces. I wasn’t sure what to do with the mail — whether we should let it sit for a few days, so any trace of the virus would die off (we knew so little back then) — but when I saw the address on the package, I couldn’t wait, and I swabbed it down with disinfectant wipes and tore it open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The Texas gunman had few friends in high school, classmates say.
description: The gunman was a high school senior who frequently missed school and struggled to get along with classmates, acquaintances said on Tuesday.
content: The gunman who fatally shot 19 children and two adults in a Texas elementary school was a high school senior who frequently missed school and struggled to get along with classmates, acquaintances said on Tuesday as they tried to make sense of the massacre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Chris Murphy, having witnessed Sandy Hook’s pain, slams fellow senators: ‘Why are you here?’
description: The Connecticut senator has made gun control his life’s work since witnessing Sandy Hook parents learning their children had been killed.
content: Senator Chris Murphy was a young United States representative from Connecticut when he stood at a firehouse in 2012 with families from his district as they learned that their children, all first graders, had been shot dead at Sandy Hook Elementary School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: New York Theater Workshop Names Patricia McGregor as Artistic Director
description: The freelance director will succeed James Nicola, who has led the Off Broadway nonprofit since 1988.
content: Patricia McGregor, a freelance director who has worked Off Broadway and around the country, has been named the next artistic director of New York Theater Workshop, a midsize nonprofit with an outsize track record of producing important work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Maya King
title: In Georgia Rematch, Stacey Abrams Fights Headwinds From Washington
description: The Democrat is facing off for a second time against Brian Kemp, a Republican — but in a far-more-difficult political climate.
content: ATLANTA — When Teaniese Davis heard that Stacey Abrams was holding a public event on Tuesday morning, she raced to a church parking lot teeming with two dozen cameras and members of the news media, hoping to catch a glimpse of one of Georgia’s most famous Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: In ‘California,’ a Road Trip and a Detour Into Darkness
description: The playwright Trish Harnetiaux’s new show, set entirely in a car, follows a family of travelers. It bravely, if not entirely satisfyingly, explores alternate realities.
content: Long ago, in a time before cellphones and overhead video players, a family road trip meant engaging in conversation, listening to the radio together or possibly sitting in more or less companionable silence for hours on end. A road trip could be a bonding experience, or it could become a contemplation of existential boredom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: More than 1 in 5 adult Covid survivors in the U.S. may develop long Covid, a C.D.C. study suggests.
description: Researchers identified lasting health problems in many different organ systems, including the heart, lungs and kidneys.
content: One in five adult Covid survivors under the age of 65 in the United States has experienced at least one health condition that could be considered long Covid, according to a large new study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Among patients 65 and older, the number is even higher: one in four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: A deadly school shooting.
content: A gunman killed at least 19 children and two adults yesterday at Robb Elementary School, an elementary school in the rural Texas community of Uvalde, west of San Antonio, officials said, in the deadliest American school shooting since the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: ‘It’s almost like an instant replay.’ Newtown parents grapple with another school shooting.
description: “I guess it’s something in society we know will happen again, over and over,” said a parent who lost a child in the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary in 2012.
content: Elizabeth Williamson is the author of “Sandy Hook: An American Tragedy and the Battle for Truth” and has spent the past four years reporting on the Newtown massacre’s aftermath and the families’ battle against misinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maya King
title: Brian Kemp trounces Trump-backed David Perdue in a Republican primary battle for Georgia governor.
description: Mr. Kemp, the incumbent, won by a wide enough margin to avoid a runoff, exposing the limits of Donald Trump’s hold on his party’s base.
content: ATLANTA — In a landslide victory that represented a resounding rebuke of Donald J. Trump, Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia won the Republican nomination for a second term on Tuesday, turning back a Trump-fueled primary challenge and delivering the former president his biggest electoral setback of the 2022 primaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: These Are Desperately Uncivil Times. We Are Disgracing America.
description: There is nothing more uncivilized than the political establishment’s inurement to the constancy of mass shootings.
content: There is a cultural obsession nowadays with civility, with the idea that if everyone is mannered enough, any impasse or difference of opinion can be bridged. But these are desperately uncivil times. And there is nothing more uncivilized than the political establishment’s inurement to the constancy of mass shootings in the United States: 60 deaths in Las Vegas, 49 deaths in Orlando, 26 deaths at Sandy Hook, 13 deaths in Columbine, 10 deaths in Buffalo. Adults, schoolchildren, concertgoers, nightclub revelers, grocery shoppers, teachers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Kate Conger
title: Twitter’s Chief Tries Staying the Course as Elon Musk Upends Plans
description: Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s chief executive, is grappling with a takeover where nobody “would want to be in those shoes.”
content: SAN FRANCISCO — At a virtual meeting for Twitter executives last week, Parag Agrawal admitted he was exhausted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Chat With Barry Bonds Helped Joc Pederson Sink the Mets
description: Pederson’s three home runs and Brandon Crawford’s walk-off single propelled the Giants to victory. The Yankees, meanwhile, are dealing with multiple injuries after a win.

title: Iraqi Man Helped Plot to Kill Bush, F.B.I. Says
description: Authorities linked the man, who was living in Ohio, to ISIS and accused him of planning to smuggle immigrants into the United States to help carry out the killing.
content: WASHINGTON — A man accused of being a member of the Islamic State helped plot to murder former President George W. Bush in retaliation for waging war against Iraq, the F.B.I. said on Tuesday.

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany plans to keep coal-fired plants ready in case Russian gas is cut.
description: The power plants, due to be shut down, would be kept in reserve to provide electricity if Russia ended shipments of natural gas.
content: Germany plans to order coal-fired power plants that were due to be shut down to be placed in reserve, as part of a plan to ensure the country can keep the lights on if supplies of natural gas from Russia are abruptly cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Digital Threads Between the U.S. and China
description: Chinese trends have shaped online experiences for Americans, and U.S. tech companies have inspired those in China.
content: As the world’s two superpowers grow further apart, the internet environments in the U.S. and China are increasingly separate digital worlds. U.S. internet companies have mostly flopped in China, and with notable exceptions, apps from China haven’t gone big outside their home country.
source.name: The New York Times
